header: What Germany Is Arguing About in the Corona Era
article:
Did the government react appropriately? Does the mask requirement make sense? On Sunday, May 10, people across Germany debated questions like these. Just how divided are they?
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
In the summer of 2017, ZEIT ONLINE
initiated a project called Germany Talks. Thousands of people signed up to meet
up with a neighbor who held contrasting political views for a face-to-face
debate. Since then, Germany Talks has taken place on a regular basis and more
than 60,000 people have taken part. On Sunday, May 10, thousands of people
around Germany met up once again to discuss the consequences of the coronavirus
pandemic – this time via video chat. Reports on the event can be read here.
Has the German government responded
correctly to the coronavirus crisis? Have the authorities been sufficiently
informative and transparent? Do mask-wearing requirements make sense? To
discuss such questions in one-on-one debates, thousands of people across
Germany met up via video chat on Sunday, May 10, as part of this year's Germany
Talks event. 
Over several weeks preceding the event,
ZEIT ONLINE and ZEIT – in cooperation with the Frankfurter Allgemeine
Zeitung, the Schwäbische Zeitung, the Rheinische Post, Chrismon
and evangelisch.de – had invited their readers to take part. Almost 9,000
people initially showed interest, answering a total of seven controversial
yes-or-no questions regarding the corona crisis. Around 6,500 people went on to
confirm their interest in participating in Germany Talks. An algorithm then
matched the participants up in pairs, with the goal of creating twosomes that
disagreed to the greatest degree possible on issues pertaining to the
coronavirus. They were then introduced via email.
The positions held by participants this
year were extremely divergent. The coronavirus has proven to be more polarizing
than any other controversial issue thus far addressed by Germany Talks events.
On average, the pairs created had different answers to 5.6 of the seven
questions. By comparison, in last year's event, which focused on issues like
migration, climate policy and equality, the debate pairs had contrasting
opinions on an average of 4.5 questions. The year before that, it was 3.3
questions.
On none of the seven questions was there a
clear majority for one or the other position. The clearest tendency was seen when
it came to passing judgment on coronavirus policies as a whole, with two-thirds
of participants saying they believed the government had reacted correctly to
the corona crisis. Around 63 percent believe the limitations on public life are
commensurate and 61 percent approve of the nationwide mask requirement. By
comparison, a representative survey found that 72 percent of Germans agree with
the measures imposed by the country's political leaders.
The group of participants in this year's Germany
Talks event was slightly older than in past years, averaging 50.9 years old.
Only 31 percent of those taking part were women, and 68 percent men. Eastern
Germans were also slightly underrepresented, as were people living in rural
areas. The participant roster of Germany Talks was not representative, yet
interesting patterns can still be found in the information they provided and in
their answers, which we analyzed anonymously

When it comes to the details of the
coronavirus measures the have been put in place, there was significant
disagreement among Germany Talks participants. Half of them believe the same
limitations should apply to both younger and older members of society, while
the other half doesn't. The question about loosening data privacy laws to
enable the more rapid tracing of infection chains proved to be similarly
controversial, with 44 percent in favor and 56 percent opposed.
Do men and women think differently about
the issues that the corona crisis has raised? Are people in eastern Germany
more skeptical when it comes to data privacy? Are younger people in Germany
less fearful than the elderly?
The generational differences are complex. The
greatest degree of acceptance for the lockdown measures among Germany Talks
participants was found in the under-30 demographic. Yet people over 65 also
showed a greater-than-average tendency to support limitations on public life and
the broad introduction of mask­-wearing requirements. The lowest level of
support for conservative coronavirus policies was among 30-to-65-year-olds. One
explanation could be that people in this age group are more affected by work furloughs
and the closures of daycare centers and schools. 
Women tend to be more supportive than men
of the coronavirus policies. They are also more likely to believe that
limitations on public life and mask-wearing requirements are justified. But
women are more skeptical when it comes to data privacy. Generally, though, the
differences between men and women proved to be smaller this year when compared
to previous Germany Talks events. That is also true of the differences between
other groups in society. As controversial as coronavirus policies have been,
the divides do not appear to run between urban and rural areas or between
eastern and western Germany.
On Sunday, May 10, thousands of
participants met up via Skype, Zoom, WhatsApp or some other platform for a
face-to-face discussion as part of Germany Talks, with some of them talking for
several hours. For many of them, it wasn't just the technology that was
unfamiliar. Discussing coronavirus policies was still so new for many
participants that their arguments were still being formed and they had never
shared them in a discussion before.
In contrast to previous years, this
iteration of Germany Talks brought people together who lived in different
regions of the country, since the discussions were to take place via video chat
anyway. It was thus the first time that people from Bavaria debated with people
from the Rhineland, Saxons with Swabians, and Thuringians with people from
Hesse – focusing their discussion on the very different approaches taken to the
virus across the country and in their regions.
It is an opportunity for the discussions
held within the framework of Germany Talks, but also for the public debate
about how we should live with the pandemic in the future. Every participant
contributed with their arguments to coming that much closer to a constructive
and respectful debate about the correct course of action in this crisis.
